title: Bondon Density
summary: Q-SMEC proprietary metric for quantifying superconducting material density optimization and energy containment efficiency.
long_explanation: Bondon density is a proprietary Q-SMEC parameter representing the optimized atomic/molecular packing density in quantum superconducting materials. Higher bondon density correlates with improved energy containment, lower losses, and enhanced signal transduction in Q-SMEC sensors. Achieved through precise control of crystal structure, doping, and multi-layer configurations.
common_pitfalls: Confusing bondon density with simple atomic density; not accounting for quantum coherence effects.

faq.q: How is bondon density different from atomic density?
faq.a: Bondon density incorporates quantum coherence, superconducting properties, and energy containment efficiency, not just atomic packing.

mastery_checklist: Connect bondon density to sensor performance
Apply DFT to predict bondon density

title: Noise Equivalent Power (NEP)
summary: Fundamental sensor metric quantifying minimum detectable power in presence of noise.
long_explanation: NEP is the incident signal power that produces signal-to-noise ratio of 1 in 1 Hz bandwidth. Lower NEP indicates better sensitivity. Measured in W/√Hz or pW/√Hz. Q-SMEC sensors achieve NEP of 0.01-1 pW/√Hz, orders of magnitude better than conventional sensors. NEP depends on detector area, temperature, material properties, and readout electronics.
common_pitfalls: Not normalizing to bandwidth; confusing NEP with sensitivity; ignoring temperature dependence.

faq.q: What NEP values are achievable with Q-SMEC?
faq.a: Q-SMEC THz sensors achieve 0.01-1 pW/√Hz, 10-100× better than conventional bolometers.

mastery_checklist: Optimize sensor design for low NEP

title: Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR)
summary: Ratio of signal power to noise power, critical metric for sensor performance.
long_explanation: SNR quantifies signal quality: SNR = P_signal / P_noise, often expressed in dB (10*log10(SNR)). Q-SMEC sensors achieve >120 dB SNR, enabling detection of extremely weak signals. High SNR improves detection range, resolution, and false alarm rates. SNR depends on sensor NEP, integration time, signal strength, and environmental conditions.
common_pitfalls: Confusing voltage SNR and power SNR; not accounting for bandwidth; ignoring coherent averaging.

faq.q: How does Q-SMEC achieve >120 dB SNR?
faq.a: Through ultra-low NEP (<1 pW/√Hz), quantum-enhanced detection, cryogenic operation, and superconducting materials.

mastery_checklist: Convert between linear and dB SNR
Understand SNR impact on detection performance

title: Figure of Merit (FOM)
summary: Composite metric combining multiple sensor parameters to quantify overall performance.
long_explanation: FOM combines sensitivity, speed, resolution, and other parameters into single performance metric. For THz sensors: FOM = (Responsivity × Bandwidth) / NEP. Q-SMEC sensors achieve FOM > 2500, indicating exceptional performance. FOM enables comparison across different sensor technologies and architectures. Higher FOM indicates better overall capability for specific application.
common_pitfalls: Using inconsistent FOM definitions; not normalizing for operating conditions; comparing incompatible sensor types.

faq.q: What does FOM > 2500 mean for Q-SMEC?
faq.a: It indicates world-class THz sensor performance, 10-100× better than conventional detectors.

mastery_checklist: Calculate FOM for different sensor types

title: Terahertz (THz) Sensing
summary: Detection and imaging in 0.1-10 THz frequency range using quantum-enhanced sensors.
long_explanation: THz radiation (100 GHz - 10 THz) penetrates many materials but is non-ionizing. Applications: security screening, non-destructive testing, 6G communications, spectroscopy, medical imaging. Q-SMEC THz sensors use superconducting materials with sub-picosecond response times and <150 nm resolution. Key challenges: atmospheric absorption, source power, detector sensitivity. Q-SMEC addresses detector limitations with quantum materials.
common_pitfalls: Ignoring atmospheric attenuation; not considering diffraction limits; underestimating thermal noise.

faq.a: THz photon energies are low (meV), making sensitive detection difficult. Atmospheric water absorption limits range.

title: Metamaterials for EM Control
summary: Engineered structures with electromagnetic properties not found in nature, enabling novel device functionalities.
long_explanation: Metamaterials achieve negative refractive index, perfect absorption, cloaking, and extreme permittivity/permeability through subwavelength structures. Q-SMEC uses quantum-optimized metamaterials for: RCS reduction (stealth), THz manipulation, perfect absorbers, and tunable EM response. Design requires computational electromagnetics (FDTD, FEM) and nanofabrication. Key parameters: unit cell geometry, material composition, thickness, periodicity.
common_pitfalls: Ignoring losses in real materials; not accounting for fabrication tolerances; oversimplifying unit cell models.

faq.q: How do Q-SMEC metamaterials reduce RCS?
faq.a: Through impedance matching, perfect absorption, and tunable complex permittivity/permeability in wideband spectrum.

title: Complex Permittivity and Permeability
summary: Complex-valued electromagnetic parameters describing material response to applied fields.
long_explanation: Complex permittivity ε = ε' - iε'' and permeability μ = μ' - iμ'' describe material EM response. Real parts (ε', μ') relate to energy storage; imaginary parts (ε'', μ'') relate to losses. Q-SMEC materials achieve tunable ε and μ through quantum optimization, enabling stealth, absorption, and sensing applications. Measurement techniques: cavity perturbation, transmission/reflection, THz-TDS.
common_pitfalls: Confusing permittivity and permeability; ignoring frequency dispersion; not measuring at relevant frequencies.

faq.q: Why tune both ε and μ?
faq.a: Simultaneous control enables impedance matching, perfect absorption, and exotic EM phenomena like negative refraction.

mastery_checklist: Design materials with target ε and μ

title: Prussian Blue Analogs (PBA)
summary: Metal-organic framework materials for advanced battery cathodes with superior cycle life and energy density.
long_explanation: PBAs have open framework structure enabling facile ion insertion/extraction. General formula: A_x M[M'(CN)6]_y where A is alkali ion, M and M' are transition metals. Q-SMEC optimizes PBA composition for: high voltage (>4V), high capacity (>170 mAh/g), long cycle life (>10,000 cycles), minimal strain. DFT calculations guide material selection. Key advantages: aqueous synthesis, abundant elements, structural stability.
common_pitfalls: Not controlling water content; ignoring defects; poor electronic conductivity without additives.

faq.q: Why are PBAs better than Li-ion cathodes?
faq.a: PBAs offer longer cycle life, faster charging, better safety, and use earth-abundant elements.

title: Quantum Magnetometry
summary: Ultra-sensitive magnetic field detection using quantum phenomena (SQUIDs, NV centers, atomic magnetometers).
long_explanation: Quantum magnetometers achieve sensitivities <0.1 fT/√Hz, enabling detection of biomagnetic signals (MEG, MCG), mineral exploration, and submarine detection. Technologies: SQUID (superconducting quantum interference device), NV-diamond, atomic vapor. Q-SMEC uses superconducting materials for low-noise, high-sensitivity magnetometry at 77-300K. Applications: medical imaging, geophysics, defense, navigation.
common_pitfalls: Not shielding environmental noise; thermal drift; ignoring gradiometer configurations.

faq.q: What sensitivity do Q-SMEC magnetometers achieve?
faq.a: <0.1 fT/√Hz for biomagnetic applications, enabling MEG/MCG without cryogenic cooling.

title: Superconducting Materials for Sensors
summary: Materials exhibiting zero electrical resistance below critical temperature, enabling ultra-sensitive sensors.
long_explanation: Superconductors enable SQUIDs, TES (transition-edge sensors), KIDs (kinetic inductance detectors), and low-noise electronics. Q-SMEC uses 22 quantum-optimized superconducting materials (10 disclosed, 12 proprietary) including: YBCO, BSCCO, NbN, NbTiN, and novel cuprates. Key parameters: Tc (critical temperature), Jc (critical current density), Hc (critical field). DFT calculations predict properties and guide synthesis.
common_pitfalls: Not accounting for flux noise; ignoring grain boundaries; poor thermal management.

faq.q: Why does Q-SMEC use multiple superconducting materials?
faq.a: Different applications require different Tc, Jc, and compatibility. Multi-layer stacks optimize performance.

title: Technology Readiness Level (TRL)
summary: NASA/DOD metric quantifying technology maturity from basic research (TRL 1) to operational deployment (TRL 9).
long_explanation: TRL scale: 1 (basic principles), 2 (concept formulated), 3 (proof of concept), 4 (lab validation), 5 (relevant environment), 6 (prototype demo), 7 (system demo), 8 (system qualified), 9 (operational). Q-SMEC instantiations target TRL 5-9 depending on application. DOE/DARPA use TRL for funding decisions. Development costs and timelines scale with TRL.
common_pitfalls: Overestimating TRL; skipping validation steps; not aligning with customer TRL requirements.

faq.a: TRL 5-7 for R&D contracts; TRL 7-9 for production programs depending on sector and application.

title: Size, Weight, Power, and Cost (SWAP-C)
summary: Key design constraints for aerospace, defense, and mobile applications requiring miniaturization and efficiency.
long_explanation: SWAP-C optimization critical for: UAVs, satellites, portable sensors, automotive, wearables. Q-SMEC addresses through: chip-scale integration, low-power operation, advanced packaging, materials optimization. Trade-offs between parameters require multi-objective optimization. Cost includes NRE (non-recurring engineering) and production costs. SWAP-C metrics drive technology selection.
common_pitfalls: Optimizing one parameter at expense of others; not accounting for thermal management; ignoring lifecycle costs.

faq.q: How does Q-SMEC achieve SWAP-C advantages?
faq.a: Through quantum materials, multi-layer integration, cryogen-free operation, and semiconductor manufacturing.

title: Cybersecurity Maturity Model Certification (CMMC)
summary: DOD framework for assessing and enhancing cybersecurity posture of defense contractors.
long_explanation: CMMC has 3 levels (1-3) requiring progressively stricter controls for Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI). Level 1: basic cyber hygiene (17 practices). Level 2: intermediate (110 practices). Level 3: advanced/progressive (130 practices). Q-SMEC sensors integrate CMMC compliance for defense applications including: hardware-based security (PUF), tamper detection, secure boot, encrypted data paths.
common_pitfalls: Not planning for certification costs; underestimating implementation time; poor documentation.

faq.q: What CMMC level does Q-SMEC target?
faq.a: Level 2-3 for defense programs handling CUI and Federal Contract Information (FCI).

title: Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program (FedRAMP)
summary: Government-wide program providing standardized approach to security assessment for cloud services.
long_explanation: FedRAMP enables federal agencies to adopt cloud services while ensuring security. Three impact levels: Low, Moderate, High. Q-SMEC cloud-based sensor networks and AI-SCADA platforms require FedRAMP authorization for federal deployments. Process: Readiness assessment → FedRAMP authorization → continuous monitoring. Key controls: NIST SP 800-53, encryption, access control, incident response.
common_pitfalls: Underestimating authorization timeline (12-18 months); poor documentation; inadequate continuous monitoring.

faq.a: For cloud-based sensor data platforms and AI analytics serving federal agencies (DOE, DHS, DOD).

title: International Traffic in Arms Regulations (ITAR)
summary: US regulations controlling export of defense and military technologies under USML (United States Munitions List).
long_explanation: ITAR restricts access to and export of defense articles, technical data, and services. Violations carry severe penalties. Q-SMEC defense sensors (ISR, EW, hypersonics, directed energy) are ITAR-controlled. Requires: registration with DDTC, export licenses, technology control plans, foreign person access restrictions. Commodity jurisdiction determines ITAR vs EAR (Export Administration Regulations).
common_pitfalls: Deemed exports to foreign nationals; insufficient access controls; poor recordkeeping; unauthorized disclosures.

faq.a: Defense ISR, EW, hypersonics, directed energy, submarine communications, and space situational awareness.
